data.title: osX JS intellisense doesn't work when jsconfig.json exists
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8 (November 2016)
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.1

**Issue**:
I am having project with native JS, ReactJS, Coffee etc. However none of those files have an intellisence when jsconfig.json is present in project root. As soon as I delete config file and reload Code, intellisence is there.

**Steps to Reproduce**:
1. On osX create project with JS files
2. Observe how JS intellisence works
3. Add jsconfig.json to project root
4. Observe how JS intellisense doesn't work

**jsconfig.json sample**
```
{
	"compilerOptions": {
		"target": "es6",
		"module": "commonjs",
		"allowSyntheticDefaultImports": true
	},
	"exclude": [
		"node_modules",
		"bower_components",
		"jspm_packages",
		"tmp",
		"temp"
	]
}
```

data.title: Update readme of JavaScript Atom Grammar
Cannot "remove" keyboard shortcuts for some built in commands.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
The following works well to remove a build in keyboard mapping.

```
  { "key": "cmd+k m",               "command": "-workbench.action.editor.changeLanguageMode" },

```

The following does not:

```
  { "key": "shift+cmd+s",           "command": "-workbench.action.files.saveAs"},
```

The reason I wanted to completely remove `shift+cmd+s` was to allow the terminal to intercept the `cmd+s/cmd+shift+s` keys when the terminal is focused. When the terminal is focused, there's no need to intercept the `cmd+s` shortcut especially.

data.title: Less stressful way to navigate Quick Open / Command pallets.
data.body: Right now, you can easily open the Quick Open / Command Pallets, and you can customize keyboard shortcuts for navigating the contents of these dialogs. However, the keyboard shortcuts have counterintuitive keyboard behavior, or at the very least a more *stressful* interaction model. Currently, when hitting "Command+P" to navigate the entries after the QuickOpen dialog is open, releasing the Command key will open the highlighted entry. This is "stressful" (on the hands) because you cannot relax your hands while navigating the items, or while casually pausing to read the list. This is different than the down/up arrow keys which seem more intuitive, or at the very least less stressful on the hands. Can we have the ability to customize alternative keyboard shortcuts that behave like down/up in this case? I would customize "ctrl-p/ctrl-n" to be up/down respectively (like the Chrome browser autocomplete does, and like the Atom command pallet does).

data.title: Introduce new vscode.newUntitled API command (fixes #17917)
data.body:
Motivation is to allow extensions to open untitled documents with a specific language. Today they can only do this by associating a file path to the untitled document with the extension of choice but that has the down side of making the untitled file save to that path which may not be desired.

Since there are likely more use cases for handling untitled files, I decided to add 2 more arguments to control the untitled file: the initial contents and the associated file path of the untitled file.

Fixes #17917

data.title: Feature request: keybindings, single/multi line selecting condition for the when clause

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.10

It would be great to have a single/multi line selection condition for the when clause on keybindings.json

This would allow to create smart keybindings, such as:

If a single line is selected, and I press CTRL+C, // is added to the beginning of the line. Otherwise, if multiple lines are selected instead, the selection is wrapped with /* */

example:
```
$a = 1; <-- selected line
$b = 2;
```
becomes:
```php
//$a = 1;
$b = 2;
```
Otherwise:
```php
$a = 1; <-- selected line
$b = 2; <-- selected line
```
becomes:
```php
/*$a = 1;
$b = 2;*/
```

data.title: Automatically expand full docstring when autocompleting
data.body:
As originally posted as a [feature request in the pythonVSCode project](https://github.com/DonJayamanne/pythonVSCode/issues/645):

Would it be possible to automatically expand the docstring without requiring clicking the "info" symbol button?

Current behavior requires you to click the "info" symbol button to view the full docstring:

![01](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/994357/21966814/2f229372-db7b-11e6-9f7d-b46ba81ba7e8.png)

![02](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/994357/21966815/32b53bb6-db7b-11e6-9264-0ee9d9c0c445.png)

For comparison, here's how Atom deals with this (always expands the full docstring):

![atom](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/994357/21966818/3ad5835a-db7b-11e6-9977-b699031f755e.png)

Also, it would be useful to be able to copy paste e.g. a function's arguments from the documentation shown.

data.title: Wrong autocompletion
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.8.1 (ee428b0eead68bf0fb99ab5fdc4439be227b6281, 2016-12-19T14:42:49.304Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.6.0
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|beautify|HookyQR|0.7.3|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.2|
|code-runner|formulahendry|0.6.5|
|ide-purescript|nwolverson|0.6.3|
|language-purescript|nwolverson|0.1.1|
|vscode-coffeelint|slb235|0.0.2|
|react-beautify|taichi|0.3.0|
|vscode-react-native|vsmobile|0.2.5|
|JavaScriptSnippets|xabikos|1.2.0|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Write something that has an autocompletion and has a dot (.) in it.
2. After inserting the dot, autocomplete the rest (by pressing _Enter_ or _Tab_ or your custom key, doesn't matter).
3. You should see that the autocompletion adds the part before the dot as well, which is undesirable. 

Here are 2 explanatory images.

Before autocompletion:
![screen shot 2017-01-16 at 00 04 48](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13895224/21966166/63bab58e-db7f-11e6-8e7b-fe052e8c5c8f.png)

After autocompletion: (I press _Enter_, and VSCode autocompletes to this)
![screen shot 2017-01-16 at 00 04 54](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13895224/21966165/63b78332-db7f-11e6-973d-db4f179a6d7e.png)

data.body:
Sort of like in Beyond Compare:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/101152/21966024/cbb765ba-db6b-11e6-8501-f8064995290e.png)

I can immediately see what changed in a line, even if that happened farther to the right (lines can be pretty long e.g. in Markdown documents or HTML). Note: in Beyond Compare, the bottom view automatically scrolls to the first diff in a line which is also useful.
